By Patricia Zengerle
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON The U.S. Senate voted overwhelmingly on Tuesday to pass a $602 billion defense authorization bill
column2: despite President Barack Obama's threat to veto the annual policy measure over issues including a ban on closing the Guantanamo Bay military prison.The vote was 85-13
column3: far more than the majority needed to pass the 100-member Senate. Six Republicans and seven members of the Democratic caucus voted against the bill
column4: which authorizes military spending for the fiscal year that begins on Oct. 1.Obama gave a long list of objections to the versions of the bill passed by the Senate and House of Representatives
column5: including provisions making it more difficult to close the detention center at the Guantanamo Bay naval base in Cuba and the use of funds specially designated for the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq to allow the military to avoid mandatory spending limits.The Senate's version of the National Defense Authorization Act
column6: or NDAA
column7: now must be reconciled with the one passed by the House last month before it can be sent to Obama. The House bill also faces a veto threat.If the bill is finished before November
column8: when every member of the House and one-third of the Senate is up for re-election
column9: a veto could prove challenging for Democrats.Obama's party is trying to keep the White House
column10: and hopes to regain the Senate majority it lost in 2014
column11: if not control of the House. But Democrats perpetually battle accusations from Republicans that they are soft on defense
column12: a fight that could be more difficult if they block the major Pentagon policy bill.

column1: 'DEATH SENTENCE'

column2: who chairs the Armed Services Committee
column3: said he was disappointed the bill did not include a program that would help Afghans who are in danger because they worked for American troops to move to the United States.

column1: They are the number one target for the Taliban and for ISIS (Islamic State)
column2: McCain said in the Senate after the bill passed without an amendment extending the program to provide Special Immigrant Visas for interpreters and others who worked for U.S. forces.Democratic Senator Jeanne Shaheen
column3: who had introduced the amendment
column4: called its omission ""unconscionable."" In a statement
column5: she said
column6: ""For many of them
column7: this could be a death sentence.""The bill would also require young women to register for the military draft
column8: as the Department of Defense opens all of the military
column10: to females. A few conservative senators voted against the measure because of that provision.

column1: The bill passed with a compromise on the use of Russian RD-180 rocket engines. Lawmakers eased a ban on their use late last year
column2: worried that it could drive United Launch alliance
column3: a joint venture of Lockheed Martin Corp and Boeing Co
column4: out of business and leave only privately held SpaceX to transport satellites into space.An amendment from Republican Senator Cory Gardner and Democrat Bill Nelson gives the Pentagon time to develop and test a replacement for the Russian-made engines and limits their use for launches.McCain
column5: a harsh critic of Moscow
column6: had tried to stop the use of the RD-180 to send a message to Russia's President Vladimir Putin. The bill also bars military base closures
column7: despite military leaders saying they have more capacity than they need. Closing bases is a thorny issue for many lawmakers
column8: especially in an election year. (Reporting by Patricia Zengerle; editing by Lisa Von Ahn

column1: 1	1	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-hack-idUSKCN0Z0205	Russians steal research on Trump in hack of U.S. Democratic Party	"
By Dustin Volz and Emily Stephenson
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Hackers believed to be working for the Russian government broke into the Democratic National Committee's computer network
column2: spied on internal communications and accessed research on presumptive Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump
column3: the committee and security experts said on Tuesday.Two separate groups entered the DNC's system
column4: and one read email and chat communications for nearly a year before being detected
column5: according to the committee and CrowdStrike
column6: the cyber firm that helped clean up the breach.Russian spies also targeted the networks of Trump and Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton
column7: as well as the computers of some Republican political action committees
column8: the Washington Post quoted U.S. officials as saying
column9: although details were not available.A Clinton campaign official said there was no evidence the campaign's information systems had been hacked.A Russian government spokesman denied involvement in the breach.""I completely rule out a possibility that the (Russian) government or the government bodies have been involved in this
column12: told Reuters in Moscow.The intrusion is emblematic of the sophistication of Russian hackers
column13: who intelligence officials have long viewed as the most talented of U.S. adversaries in cyberspace.The Democratic Party had been aware of efforts to hack Trump material for two months
column14: and U.S. intelligence agencies were involved in efforts to find out who was behind the hacking
column15: a source familiar with Trump opposition research said.The source said Democratic Party operatives believed the hacking was conducted by the Russian government. The research includes material on Trump's business efforts in Azerbaijan
column18: according to information made available to Reuters.

column1: Cyber attacks against political candidates and organizations are common worldwide. U.S. National Intelligence Director James Clapper said last month he was aware of attempted hacks on campaigns and related groups and he expected to see more as the Nov. 8 presidential election nears.U.S. Representative Jim Langevin
column2: a Democrat and co-founder of the congressional cybersecurity caucus
column3: said it was ""disconcerting"" that independent groups penetrated the DNC and that one was able ""to stay embedded for nearly a year.""But the groups are extremely sophisticated
column4: Langevin said
column5: and have previously been implicated on attacks at the White House
column6: the State Department and the German Bundestag
column7: as well as a number of private companies.RUSSIAN BEARS ON THE LOOSE

column1: The DNC contacted CrowdStrike in May and within 24 hours it began investigating unusual activity on the group's network
column2: said Dmitri Alperovitch
column3: the company's co-founder and chief technology officer. It identified two hacking groups and both were kicked out this weekend
column4: he said.The first
column5: which CrowdStrike named Cozy Bear
column6: entered the DNC's systems last summer
column7: according to the firm. It primarily monitored email and chat conversations and may be working for Russia's Federal Security Service
column9: Alperovitch said. Russian President Vladimir Putin once ran the FSB.The second group
column11: is probably working on behalf of Russia's military
column12: Alperovitch said. It gained entry in late April and ""went straight to the oppo research ... on Donald Trump and exfiltrated some of it

column1: Alperovitch said both groups were among ""the best threat actors that we've ever encountered"" but they did not appear to be working together. He was not sure how the intrusions occurred but suspected the hackers may have leveraged ""spearphishing"" emails to trick DNC employees into downloading malicious code onto their network.""When we discovered the intrusion
column2: we treated this like the serious incident it is
column3: Rep. Debbie Wasserman Schultz
column4: chairwoman of the DNC
column5: said in a statement. ""Our team moved as quickly as possible to kick out the intruders and secure our network.""Trump's interest in Russia goes back to the 1980s
column6: with a 1990 Vanity Fair article citing news program appearances in which Trump offered his own services as a negotiator with Russia. Information made available to Reuters indicates Trump tried on at least three occasions - in 2004
column7: 2008 and 2013 - to get involved in business deals in Russia.In 2013
column10: jointly put on a Miss Universe competition in Moscow
column11: and Trump was photographed with Agalarov's wife
column12: son and daughter.The last two U.S. presidential cycles in 2008 and 2012 witnessed a barrage of cyber attacks from a range of adversaries targeting President Barack Obama's campaign and the campaigns of his Republican foes.U.S. intelligence officials have said many previous assaults were linked to Chinese hackers. (Reporting by Dustin Volz
column15: Roberta Rampton and Susan Heavey in Washington and Vladimir Soldatkin in Moscow; Additional reporting by Mark Hosenball in Zurich; Writing by John Whitesides and Mohammad Zargham; Editing by James Dalgleish)"	['Langevin'

column1: 2	2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-new-jersey-christie-bridge-idUSKCN0Z02VJ	Former allies of NJ's Christie fail to dismiss Bridgegate indictment	"
By Jonathan Stempel

A federal judge refused to dismiss a criminal indictment against two former allies of New Jersey Republican Governor Chris Christie over their alleged roles in the 2013 George Washington Bridge lane-closing scandal
column2: known as Bridgegate.In a decision made public on Tuesday
column3: U.S. District Judge Susan Wigenton
column4: in Newark
column5: New Jersey
column6: rejected arguments by William Baroni and Bridget Anne Kelly that the laws under which they were charged were too vague and that they had no reason to know some of their activities might have been illegal.Kelly
column7: a former Christie deputy chief of staff
column9: a former deputy executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey
column11: civil rights deprivation and conspiracy for allegedly arranging the September 2013 shutdown of bridge access lanes in Fort Lee
column12: New Jersey.The closure led to several days of gridlock affecting the bridge
column14: which spans the Hudson River to connect New Jersey to Manhattan. Prosecutors said it was intended to punish Fort Lee's Democratic mayor for not endorsing Christie's successful reelection bid.In her 23-page decision
column15: Wigenton said reasonable public officials would understand that wrongdoing attributed to the defendants would violate drivers' right to travel.

column1: Political payback is not a significant government interest
column2: she wrote.Wigenton also said it was for jurors to decide whether to hold the defendants criminally responsible for their alleged dealings with former Port Authority executive David Wildstein
column3: who pleaded guilty to conspiracy charges and is cooperating with prosecutors.Michael Baldassare and Michael Critchley
column4: lawyers who represent Baroni and Kelly respectively
column5: did not immediately respond to requests for comment.

column1: A trial is scheduled for Sept. 12
column2: court records show.Christie has not been charged and has denied involvement in wrongdoing
column3: but the scandal hurt his popularity within New Jersey and weighed on his unsuccessful 2016 presidential run.

column1: Both defendants are also seeking records from Christie's cellphone through subpoenas to a law firm that previously generated a taxpayer-funded report absolving the governor of wrongdoing. Critics of Christie have called that report biased.Separately
column2: a federal appeals court in Philadelphia is weighing requests by media to publicly release a list of unindicted co-conspirators. Oral arguments were heard on June 6.The case is U.S. v. Baroni et al
column3: U.S. District Court
column4: District of New Jersey
column5: No. 15-cr-00193.     (Reporting by Jonathan Stempel in New York; Editing by Leslie Adler)"	['Hudson'

column1: 3	3	http://reuters.com/article/us-venezuela-oas-kerry-idUSKCN0Z027T	Kerry launches talks with Venezuela but backs disputed referendum	"
By Lesley Wroughton
| SANTO DOMINGO
SANTO DOMINGO U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry announced high-level talks to ease tensions with Venezuela's socialist government on Tuesday
column2: just hours after he backed calls for a referendum that could force President Nicolas Maduro from office.  Kerry said the talks would start immediately in Caracas and be led by Thomas Shannon
column3: a veteran of U.S. diplomacy in the region. Attempts last year at dialogue between the ideological foes were stalled by Venezuela's deepening crisis.The two countries have been embroiled in diplomatic hostilities since the administrations of Venezuelan President Hugo Chavez and U.S. President George W. Bush. Kerry said the goal was to go beyond ""the old rhetoric.""""I've committed to see if this can work so let's see if we can improve the relationship
column4: he told reporters
column5: after huddling with his Venezuelan counterpart on the sidelines of an Organization of American States (OAS) meeting in the Dominican Republic.The talks would also be aimed at fostering dialogue between Venezuela's government and opposition
column6: Kerry said.Maduro welcomed the proposed talks and repeated his suggestion that the two sides restore ambassadors in each other's capitals after an eight-year hiatus that began when Chavez expelled the U.S. envoy to Venezuela.""I propose to John Kerry 'let's designate ambassadors'
column7: I am ready. They have ambassadors in Beijing
column9: and they don't have one in Caracas
column10: he said in a speech to teachers.Maduro proposed an ambassador in 2014 but U.S. President Barack Obama has not yet accepted his credentials.

column1: FIREWORKS AT ASSEMBLY
Once one of Latin America's most prosperous nations
column2: Venezuela has plunged into unrest and a harsh economic slowdown. Long lines for food and medicines have led to protests and opposition calls for a recall referendum to remove Maduro.    That measure is allowed under the constitution
column3: a point made by Kerry to reporters after he met Venezuelan Foreign Minister Delcy Rodriguez. Earlier in the day
column4: in a speech to OAS delegates
column5: Kerry gave his backing to the referendum push and called on Chavez's political heirs to release political prisoners and respect fundamental rights.     His comments to the 34 members of the main diplomatic body of the Americas marked the strongest show of support yet from the United States for the disputed referendum process.

column1: Venezuela's opposition accuses the election council of stalling the recall at the behest of Maduro by arbitrarily changing criteria for requesting a recall vote. Maduro has said any recall against him would be in 2017 at the earliest
column2: pushing back against opposition pressure.Several opposition politicians are in jail
column3: notably hardline leader Leopoldo Lopez
column4: who has a 14-year sentence for inciting 2014 anti-government protests that spiraled into violence killing more than 40 people. The government denies it holds political prisoners.Kerry's comments drew a furious response from Rodriguez
column5: who accused Washington and OAS chief Luis Almagro of ""international bullying.""  ""Every day we have evidence of the secretary general's bias in favor of sectors of the opposition who are seeking a coup in Venezuela
column6: she said.

column1: I see now this is ordered by Washington. I know they are on Washington's payroll to meddle in the domestic affairs of Venezuela
column2: she said
column3: speaking through a translator. Kerry was more conciliatory after his first ever bilateral meeting with Rodriguez
column4: saying the United States did not support a push by Almagro to suspend Venezuela from the OAS for alleged violations of the regional group's ""democratic charter.""""The United States is not taking that position
column5: we are not pushing for a suspension. I don't think that would be constructive
column6: he said.At Almagro's behest
column7: the OAS will hold a meeting later this month to initiate the process that could end in Venezuela's suspension. But the former Uruguayan foreign minister appears isolated in the group
column8: with even right-wing governments opposed to Maduro in the region balking at throwing Venezuela out.Venezuela and the United States have repeatedly gone through periods of diplomatic fighting followed by generally short-lived eras of reconciliation. Following Washington's 2014 rapprochement with Cuba
column9: Shannon met with a top Venezuelan Socialist Party official to improve ties with Caracas. The good mood soured within months when the United States criticized the sentence handed to opposition leader Lopez. (Reporting by Lesley Wroughton; Additional reporting by Brian Ellsworth in Caracas and Jorge Pineda in Santo Domingo; Writing by Frank Jack Daniel; Editing by Tom Brown)"	['Long'

By Diane Bartz
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON Four U.S. senators - two Democrats and two Republicans - introduced a bill on Tuesday aimed at preventing big pharmaceutical companies from using safety rules to prevent generic drugs from coming to market.Senators Charles Grassley
column2: chair of the Judiciary Committee
column3: and Patrick Leahy
column4: the top Democrat
column5: are sponsors of the bill along with Senators Mike Lee and Amy Klobuchar
column6: the chair of the antitrust subcommittee and top Democrat
column8: which ensures the safety of the country's food and drug supply
column9: has a risk evaluation and mitigation strategy program
column11: which is designed to ensure that the riskiest drugs are dispensed safely.But there have been complaints that the program has been misused by brand-name drug companies to prevent generic manufacturers from getting the drug samples needed to market cheaper versions. Generic companies also complain their drugs are not allowed to share a safety protocol
column12: making it difficult to come to market.The bill would allow a generic manufacturer who faces either of these situations to file a lawsuit to force access to a sample or force negotiations for a safety protocol.

column1: Balancing the cost of developing lifesaving medications with the need to make available affordable prescription drugs to consumers has always been a difficult task. It's a consistent topic at my town meetings
column2: Grassley said in a statement.""Unfortunately
column3: we're seeing some brand-name drug companies engage in anti-competitive tactics that delay entry of lower cost generic drugs into the market. This bill takes important steps to ensure that our laws are not frustrated.""There is a similar bill in the House of Representatives which addresses the same issue but uses a different strategy. For example
column4: it requires the generic company seeking a REMS drug to get FDA authorization to obtain the sample.

column1: In one of the REMS disputes which is public

column3: accusing it of using REMS to prevent generic copies of Thalomid and Revlimid to market.The Senate Judiciary Committee's antitrust panel will hold a hearing on its bill on June 21.

column1: The Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America
column2: or PhRMA
column3: which counts major drugmakers among its members
column4: said it had no immediate comment.The Generic Pharmaceutical Association was pleased to see the bill introduced.""It is worth noting and recognizing recent efforts by representatives in the branded industry to highlight the valuable role generic medicines play in driving healthcare system savings

column6: GPhA's president. ""Continued use of these anticompetitive practices by certain manufacturers drives the exact opposite outcome."" (Reporting by Diane Bartz

column1: 5	5	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-poll-idUSKCN0Z02MK	Trump gains slightly on Clinton after Florida attack: Reuters/Ipsos poll	"
By Chris Kahn
| NEW YORK

The proportion of voters who said they would not vote for either candidate has risen steadily over the past week. About 22.4 percent of likely voters would not pick either candidate
column2: according to the five-day average of results on Tuesday. That was up from 20.6 percent a week ago.

column1: Trump's strident tone on Muslims and national security appears to have helped him in the past

column1: 6	6	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-congress-idUSKCN0Z02PO	House votes to protect 'dark money' political donors	"
By David Morgan
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON The Republican-controlled U.S. House of Representatives voted on Tuesday to protect the identities of wealthy individuals and others who make anonymous
column2: or ""dark money
column3: donations to politically active nonprofit groups.The measure
column4: which drew lobbying support from billionaire industrialists Charles and David Koch
column5: was approved in a 240-180 vote along party lines. It would prohibit the Internal Revenue Service from collecting the names and addresses of donors who contribute $5
column6: 000 or more to 501(c) organizations
column7: a name that refers to the tax code section that covers them. The action sent the bill on to the Senate.Although the measure would apply to all 501(c) tax-exempt groups
column10: politically active nonprofits are the intended beneficiaries.Republicans said the legislation would prevent the Internal Revenue Service from targeting conservative groups following 2013 revelations that Tea Party organizations were subjected to extra scrutiny.Political spending by nonprofit groups including the Koch- aligned Americans for Prosperity has grown dramatically since 2010
column11: when the Supreme Court opened the way to unlimited spending on political campaigns by individuals
column13: unions and other groups in its landmark Citizens United ruling.

column1: The White House on Monday said it opposed the bill
column2: the Preventing IRS Abuse and Protecting Free Speech Act
column3: claiming it would constrain the IRS from enforcing tax laws and reduce transparency among private foundations.Democrats argued that the legislation could make it easier for foreign entities to finance political campaigns inside the United States. Charity regulators have also warned that the loss of donor information would make it harder to protect the public against charity fraud. The change would reduce available information on a range of organizations
column4: IRS data shows.

column1: Republicans said the bill is necessary to protect donors from potential leaks that could subject them to harassment. Donor identities are not supposed to be released to the public
column2: hence the term ""dark money."" But leaks have occurred
column3: including the 2012 release of donors to the conservative National Organization for Marriage that resulted in a settlement requiring the IRS to pay the organization $50

column1: Supporters of the legislation also pointed to signs that the IRS may seek to end the disclosure requirement on its own.    Nonprofit groups could spend more than $500 million on this year's presidential and congressional elections
column2: up from $10 million in 2008
column3: according to the nonpartisan Center for Responsive Politics.House Republicans are also pushing to censure and impeach IRS Commissioner John Koskinen for allegedly failing to cooperate with a probe of the IRS scandal.   (Reporting by David Morgan; Editing by Leslie Adler)"	[]	[]

column1: 7	7	http://reuters.com/article/us-dupont-m-a-dowchemical-idUSKCN0Z02NE	Justice Department should analyze Dow-DuPont deal: senator	"
By Tom Polansek
| CHICAGO

CHICAGO The chairman of the U.S. Senate Judiciary Committee on Tuesday urged federal antitrust officials to conduct a ""careful analysis"" of Dow Chemical Co's proposed $130 billion merger with DuPont
column2: adding pressure on officials to scrutinize how rapid consolidation in agriculture will affect farmers and consumers.U.S. Senator Charles Grassley called for the review in a letter to the U.S. Department of Justice's antitrust division. column4: the world's top seed maker

column6: or ChemChina

That has eaten into sales of the big six agrochemical and seed companies that are now looking to bolster profits through mergers and partnerships.

column1: Dow expects the regulatory review of its proposed merger with DuPont ""will be a thorough process
column2: a company spokeswoman said. The deal is ""pro-competitive and good for farmers and consumers
column3: she said.Dow has previously said it expects the deal to close in the second half of 2016.
